overview_of_class: This course explores current problems in public and environmental health, such as the worldwide burden of major infections diseases; the emergence and re-emergence of new pathogens, environmental reservoirs of infectious organisms, transport of microorganisms in the environment, and evaluating the combined effects of land use modification, water abstraction, and global climate change on ecosystems.
name: Environmental Microbiology
title: MEAS CIV_ENV 361-1-20 Environmental Microbiology

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores current problems in public and environmental health, such as the worldwide burden of major infections diseases; the emergence and re-emergence of new pathogens, environmental reservoirs of infectious organisms, transport of microorganisms in the environment, and evaluating the combined effects of land use modification, water abstraction, and global climate change on ecosystems.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Understand the science of epidemiology and discuss major infectious diseases, clinical presentation, epidemiology, and treatment; their development and transmission in the environment; limitations and challenges in controlling/eradicating disease; and global surveillance and intervention programs.
2. Understand the major technological breakthroughs that have successfully been used to prevent the spread of infectious diseases, including vaccination, social public health programs, effective surveillance and outbreak management schemes, drinking water treatment, and sanitation.
3. Understand causes of disease emergence and re-emergence, including both purely biological factors such as mutation and factors related to human population dynamics, land development, and spatial organization of modern human societies.
4. Understand the effects of human perturbations on the structure and function of natural ecosystems, including effects associated with reduction of habitat, fragmentation of ecosystems, alteration of flow regimes and water chemistry, and global climate change.
5. Propose solutions for the Millennium Global Health Challenges: 1) improve existent vaccines and develop new vaccines; 2) control insects that transmit agents of disease; 3) improve drug treatment of infectious diseases 4) cure latent and chronic infections; 5) measure disease and health status accurately and economically in poor countries.
6. Propose sustainable solutions for integrated management of water and food supplies, protection of human health, and preservation of natural ecosystems.
7. Develop critical thinking and communication skills through execution of group projects.
